post tc anxiety hi all, just venting some steam off here. so, last august i found a lump, i had a ct, an op to remove my left testicle and then on 02 october was officially diagnosed with stage 2a testicular cancer. since then i ve had chemo, radiotherapy and as of a few weeks ago my first scans are normal meeting with the onco. hooray! that said, the health anxiety i m experiencing is taking the piss. every little ache, twitch, twinge, anything makes me worry unnecessarily. as a result of the radiotherapy my guts have been a bit iffy since, but a recent toothache caused me to take a lot of ibuprofen, which together with the radiotherapy caused me some really dire constipation. this lead to a hemorrhoid. it s internal and normal ly i can t feel it unless i ve sat on something cold in which case it throbs for a few minutes and then stops. occasionally there s a spot or two of blood on my crap, and one occasion i had such a large bowel movement that it turned the toilet water bright, bright red, but otherwise my bms are consistent size, shape, colour and bloodless they just scratch a little as they pass. i m improving my diet to include more fibre so hopefully it ll sort itself out. right now i want to concentrate on the future. i ve been given a new lease of life, but i feel that all the residual after effects are holding me back and the worry over everything my body does is becoming quite a burden.
the cycle starts again i'm diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder but only this year have i experienced the terror of health anxiety. i went through a throat infection, which i of course thought was cancer at first, i spent hours rechecking and researching my symptoms, which started to completely take over my life. i couldn't go a second without a distraction. after the infection cleared up i was basically rid of my fears. except a few days ago, i had an incredibly terrifying panic attack. i was just lying in bed and i had this faint pain in my left arm and for some reason my brain just short circuited, i jumped up, my heart started racing which led me to think i was having a heart attack. i genuinely thought i was going to die, i felt dizzy and for the first time i couldn't calm myself down. i was terrified so i went to see my mother and i just crawled into her arms like a 20 year old baby and after a few minutes everything went back to normal. and now i'm back in the cycle again. asking myself what if that wasn't a panic attack? and other completely illogical questions. i keep checking my heart beat, sometimes i get a spike of anxiety when i think it's too slow and same for when i believe it's too fast. i can't break out of this and it's taking over everything i'm so scared and so sick of living like this, does anyone have any advice on how to just make my brain chill for like just a second?

post tc anxiety hi all, just venting some steam off here. so, last august i found a lump, i had a ct, an op to remove my left testicle and then on 02 october was officially diagnosed with stage 2a testicular cancer. since then i ve had chemo, radiotherapy and as of a few weeks ago my first scans are normal meeting with the onco. hooray! that said, the health anxiety i m experiencing is taking the piss. every little ache, twitch, twinge, anything makes me worry unnecessarily. as a result of the radiotherapy my guts have been a bit iffy since, but a recent toothache caused me to take a lot of ibuprofen, which together with the radiotherapy caused me some really dire constipation. this lead to a hemorrhoid. it s internal and normally i can t feel it unless i ve sat on something cold in which case it throbs for a few minutes and then stops. occasionally there s a spot or two of blood on my crap, and one occasion i had such a large bowel movement that it turned the toilet water bright, bright red, but otherwise my bms are consistent size, shape, colour and bloodless they just scratch a little as they pass. i m improving my diet to include more fibre so hopefully it ll sort itself out. right now i want to concentrate on the future. i ve been given a new lease of life, but i feel that all the residual after effects are holding me back and the worry over everything my body does is becoming quite a burden.
love yourself take care of yourself. historically, for me.. january march is the hardest time for year for me. my anxiety journey began two years ago, in february. one of my best friends passed from a brain tumor, the month before. i went to his funeral and they talked about all the symptoms he had.... next thing i know, i m consumed by constantly looking for the same symptoms. then they start to appear.... one day, i m fine. the next day i have a pain in my neck and googled it and was convinced it was cancer and i was going to die and leave my young wife and daughter. then i had a full blown panic attack on valentine s day and ended up in the er, convinced i was having a heart attack. since then, it has been on and off struggles with a brain tumor fear my longest battle. but every january, the anxiety comes back with a vengeance. i know this is the case for a lot of people... the bad weather, the dark days with not a lot to do, it takes a toll. remember. take care of yourself. excercise, hell even just go on a walk. distract yourself. don t seclude yourself. don t google. eat your greens. take care of yourself. we re all fighting the same battle. we re all constantly battling with the very real symptoms that our bodies have. the very real fear of passing before your time, or having a terminal disease. i care about each and every one of you. hang in there. and let s fight the good fight every day.
i had no idea so many people were like me. ever since i was 15 16 i had panic attacks from thinking i was having a stroke or heart attacks or cancer etc. first was walking home from school started feeling very thirsty and hot then dizzy called 911 thinking i was dying having a heat stroke. doc told me i had a panic attack. now i'm 25 and been in and out of work due to my panic attacks or just the anxiety of having panic attacks. im super depressed and have no drive to be the best me anymore. i feel stuck and like i'll never get better. pot works wonders but unfortunately i don't live in a legal state. and since i'm looking for a job i can't use it i have to rely on my clonopin which only helps if i catch the panic attack in time. i get pains or find something wrong on my body and assume the worst instantly and go full panic mode. fucking sucks. it's ruined my life, all i do now is put in job applications and play bfv to keep my mind off my body. last income i've had was from a guy i used to work concrete construction with who hires me as a ranch hand ever so often but only for about a week a year. my father supports me but i hate relying on him because he barely makes any money doing what he does and we are always short on food because rent and utilities come first. i hate doing this to him. i'm fucking 25 i should be out doing my own think not seizuring out thinking i'm dying 2 4 times a week.
up and down so, my health anxiety focuses on getting pregnant i m terrified of it, don t ever want to be i m 20 and no doctor will tie my tubes. i thought either my contraceptive implant was broken, i would do pregnancy tests and not trust the result or go digging through the bin for them, i didn t trust a blood test, i thought every twinge in my body was a symptom. i thought i saw signs everywhere telling me i was pregnant. then, last week, after 3 cbt sessions, upping my anti depressants and travelling home to see my parents for the first time in 4 weeks, i had the first good week since september. no tests, no doctor visits, plenty of exercise, could snap myself out of any dangerous thought patterns. no googling! i was so happy and proud. i even had sex for the first time in 4 months with my boyfriend. then, on saturday morning, my boyfriend accidentally grabbed my arm implant. since then, i feel like i ve spiralled back of control after just one week of happiness. i ve resisted doing a test so far, but i swear my implant is broken even after seeing a nurse, i m symptom spotting, googling, crying etc. my techniques to cope aren t working. i go from feeling scared and upset to angry with myself and the world. i was just wondering, how do people cope with these type of set backs? how do you pull yourself up again? at the minute i just feel sad and depressed and angry. fuck you, health anxiety.
rabies anxiety so, i have pretty severe rabies anxiety, which usually only acts up in the summer. i'm lucky in that i don't really worry about cats or dogs, since i next to never interact with them, but i'm absolutely terrified of a rabid bat getting into my room and biting me without my knowing it. we've had bats in our house twice now, and maybe two or three years ago, finally did an exclusion in our attic and had a professional go around and seal everything up. i haven't slept with my window open at night for several years now, but last night, i left it open by mistake until around 4 in the morning which, naturally, set off my anxiety. i have a screen on my window, which sort of sets against a little interior strip of wood, but it isn't tightly sealed, and there's one side that's actually quite loose big enough that a bat probably could get through . i'm trying to be very logical about this, but i'm struggling. i was in my room basically all night until i went to bed at around 4 am , and never saw a bat, or heard anything against the screen, but just knowing that my window was open, and what if a bat got in while i wasn't looking or when i left the room or something? reasonably, i know a sick bat wouldn't be able to get back out if one had gotten in, and i don't think there's any way i wouldn't notice a bat flying around healthy or otherwise! but it's very hard to convince myself of that.
just when i think i've made it, i get pulled back in. i've had so many tests, painful and otherwise, over the past several weeks. after finally getting a nearly clean bill of health, i brought up with my doctor the one thing i didn't think about until recently. i could feel a swollen lymph node just under my jaw over my carotid artery. what started to scare me, is that i realized i could feel that lymph node for something like 3 months . my doctor immediately ordered an ultrasound, and this morning i got a really somber call from a nurse at the dr.'s office saying i needed to see an ent right away i not only have the one, but multiple enlarged lymph nodes in that area. my understanding is that the concern from my doctor is not just that there are multilple and they're enlarged at least one is on the order of 2cm , but that at least one has persisted for so long, and even more alarming, i have no signs of an infection and my bloodwork is clean apparently persistent enlarged, multiple lymph nodes with clean bloodwork is not a good sign. i've been freaking out all day and i've been trying to avoid the internet, but the soonest i can get in to see an ent is next tuesday, so i get to spend the next 4 days agonizing about this. i'm 38 years old, and i've been through so many health symptom scares over the past couple of months mostly heart related that the anxiety is just making me lose my mind...
booked a health test total regression hi, i've experienced health anxiety on and off for most of my life. it has become a lot better over the years and i have found ways to cope and calm myself down. i'm not the ha type that goes to doctors a lot actually almost never partly because my rational part knows that it's just ha and partly because it's so crazy expensive. my main tools for managing ha has been act normal even if i feel worried and obsess, do not take action don't look for reassurance, don't see a doctor, don't google don't feed the monster , setting a specific time when it's ok to worry between 6 7 at night, worry time. at other times, just postpone it. and writing down what i worry about. it's been going well for the last few years and i almost considered myself cured . until i decided to go for an extensive health check with a battery of tests. there's no particular symptom that brought on this, just that it's something i should start doing regularly at my age. what normal people do. however, as soon as i booked the test and got the list of tests, ha totally exploded. in a way worse than the usual ha where i used to focus on just a few illnesses now i basically convinced that with that many tests and possible cancers, i must check positive for at least one! has anyone else experience this kind of setback and how did you cope? i still have two three more weeks before the results.

scared about temporal arteritis adding to all the cancers and heart conditions i've been worried about, i just read about temporal arteritis and i'm worried about it too. i'm a 23 year old white male. for the past couple days i've had tenderness near my right temple only. there's no constant pain, but it hurts when i put mild to moderate pressure on a certain part of the bone behind under the temple. i can feel a slight bump there but there's an essentially symmetrical one on the other side with no tenderness with the same amount of pressure . i do have many other symptoms of temporal arteritis, including frequent headaches although generally mild , tiredness in limbs, and general tiredness, but i've had all that for a long time and often can be traced to specific causes like poor sleeping habits and dehydration. i don't have any of the jaw pain or tiredness any more so than i would normal ly get after chewing for a long time anyway , although sometimes my mouth does feel slightly stiff if i haven't opened it for a while. i do have a bad habit of clenching grinding my teeth that i've had for most of my life, and i've had tmj associated pain before. i don't think i've had any vision loss, but sometimes i do find it harder to focus or i feel like i'm not seeing quite as well when i' tired so i can't say for sure. i don't have any other tender points on my scalp, just the right temple.

going out on a limb here anyone else have benign brain calcification? i used to work at a cancer hospital and had severe health anxiety about brain tumors. i went to several doctors, all of which said i was healthy. i finally worked up the courage to go to a neurologist and upon seeing how anxious i was, she gave me a brain mri. it turns out that i had an incidental finding which was benign brain calcification . she said it is unremarkable and the rest was deemed normal . i had another ct a year later, and the size was unchanged. so that could indicate i ve just had it my whole life and means nothing, and they pushed the next ct to 5 years away which would be next year or the year after . they did say that if i m having symptoms such as a headache they gave no other symptoms , that we can schedule it sooner. i m just terrified that it s multiplying in my brain right now or something. i have terrible health anxiety and get horrible symptoms, especially with vision. i m just nervous that it s the calcification causing this and not my anxiety. has anyone else had experience with this? or any doctors that can give me some reassurance? i know i should just make an appointment with the neurologist, but she already thinks i m crazy and told me to see a psychologist about my anxiety which i do lol. thanks on advance!
driving suggestions tips that helped me i hate driving to new places, and this has helped me tons 1. pre research the address if the time is flexible, what times are the least busy google maps is a good one to check . is the destination open check the website ahead of time . 2. use street view to check out the entire route. 3. get your nav app all ready. i ve found that apple maps if you have this is amazing because it will say things like don t make right after this stoplight. make a right at the next one. the destination is in the right, pull into the next driveway on your left, etc. 4. leave with plenty of time to spare. assume you will make a few wrong turns. give yourself extra time to lose your way. 5. research parking ahead of time. use apps like parking hero. use the city s websites to find out the capacity of municipal parking ramps, if available. scope out street parking with google street view, too. 6. find alternatives to parallel parking. you can also park near driveways, so you can t get parked in easy pull in out . 7. dress comfortably so that if you get stressed, you won t get super sweaty. 8. make sure you have enough gas 9. adjust your mirrors, clean windows, headlights for visibility, ahead of time 10. listen to calming music driving playlist 11. get toll money ez pass ready ahead of time

possible explanation for brain fog, headaches, fatigue, dizziness with normal lab imaging findings hi all, i really hope this doesn't stir up more anxiety for anyone, but i have a possible explanation for some of the symptoms that often pop up here, especially for the folks that think they have a brain tumor. when the bones of the neck are not in proper alignment a lordotic curve , whether from past trauma e.g. whiplash, repetitive micro trauma , or poor posture, it can cause a bunch of symptoms that a lot of people are attributing to brain tumors headaches, dizziness, vision issues, brain fog, fatigue etc. . a formal x ray ct mri report will not usually comment on an absent lordotic curve if there is nothing pathologically wrong bone spurs, herniations etc. with the vertebrae or disc space, but a non lordotic curve does cause real symptoms. i came across this information through physio chiro, so if you're someone that slouches and has migraines and headaches, try keeping your chin tucked in, don't stay in awkward positions, take breaks from computer work, drink water, get a comfortable pillow, and keep your shoulders rolled back. i know not everyone's issues are related to this but it may be worth a try if your medical tests all came back negative but you're still experiencing symptoms.

constantly checking for signs of brain problem hey, guys. so this is a little difficult to explain, so hopefully i can describe it as cohesively as possible. so, a couple months ago i developed a little obsession with misreading things. i misread a couple of words and immediately began to think there is something wrong with my brain . well now, it s manifested itself in just about everything. in a bizarre way to prove i do don t have a problem, i ve begun subconsciously checking every thing i read and hear to see if i made a mistake. for instance, i ll skim a headline really fast online, then get frustrated when i misread it even though i didn t carefully read it . because i m now checking every single word i read and hear, i m constantly misreading, mishearing and misunderstanding things, because i m focusing on each individual word and not the sentence as a whole. it s mentally exhausting and is effecting my reasoning skills and memory, which of course, is fueling my health anxiety as it further proves i have something wrong with me. of course, occupying my mind with this causes me to make many, many mistakes which you guessed it fuels it more. has anyone else struggled with health anxiety pertaining to a brain problem? this really sucks.

can t do this anymore. as the title says i really can t do this anymore, living with anxiety and health anxiety isn t even living it s basically existing. it s got to the point that it s changing who i am as a person, i ve become jealous of people for being able to just live their lives, i feel like i m becoming a bad mum and partner through it and i ve decided it s time for a change. instead of going to the doctor for yet more tablets i ve decided to overcome it myself, eating better, sleeping better, avoiding alcohol i ve realised this does not help at all it helps while i m drinking and then the next day is hell avoiding caffeine and exercising and reading more. i ve started playing the sims on my phone just to keep my mind active and on something other than my health or whatever strange worry my mind decides to have that day. i ve decided enough is enough and i m going to push myself to do things i would never usually do and get better. sorry for the moaning boring post but sometimes it feels good to get it out to people who actually know how you feel and won t just say you ll be alright also a great app i ve found is called dare it s absolutely brilliant for panic attacks and has really helped me the last few days. thanks for reading.
anxiety over therapy hii! i live in belarus and in my country there are no cbt practitioners. all our doctors can offer is pills. maybe talking therapy. i don't want to spend my time just talking about my anxiety, it's not gonna help. i've been struggling with anxiety throughout my life. i had ocd sometimes still have it , but overcame it on my own using internet and articles of dr. steven phillipson. i had gad just general anxiety 24 7 and overcame it by accepting using the book by claire weekes hope and help for your nerves . now i suffer from severe health anxiety. i've read some books and other sufferers on forums told me some techniques. what i've been using is more act acceptance and commitment therapy than cbt. and it was quite helpful for me. i have always had problems challenging the thought, it's much easier to accept it and let it float past me as clouds as just anxiety . lately i've read on wikipedia that cbt is a gold standard approach. and developed anxiety what if yess classic what if thought the approach you've been using is wrong and is not recognized by therapists? . i lack confidence, although i have tools. but i continue googling. i understand this is just another anxiety about the therapy maybe a sign i'm recovering.

how do we know that it is svt rather than vtach? very rarely, i will have these 5 to 10 minute episode of sudden high heart rate, above 180. i learned that this is may be svt. i have already seen a cardiologist and she did all sorts of tests and concluded my heart is structurally normal and there is no worry. but no test has ever been able to catch these rare racing heart issue of mine. i have had these since i was a kid, decades ago. and i do have them every couple of months or sometimes there will be 1 or 2 years between attacks . no other symptoms except the racing heart which feels like it's lightly beating so fast i once counted up to 200 bpm . on holter the worst they caught was a few isolated pacs. amp x200b now i have been reading about vtach and this seems to be dangerous kind of arrythmia because there is a chance if can go to vfib. yeah, we anxiety sufferers are a hypochondriac bunch. amp x200b so how do i know what i have all along is not vt? now i am so afraid to be left alone and so afraid of those attacks whereas before i learned about vt, i did not mind them too much as my cardiologist assured me i am okay. but now, i am always thinking what if these are sustained vt rather than a more benign tachycardia??

my hiv health anxiety nightmare i participated in a low risk activity. it is estimated the chances of acquiring hiv are about 1 in 2,500. nevertheless, it has happened. 4.5 weeks later i got the flu. cue health anxiety meltdown. i tested at 5.5 weeks. negative. 3 other tests later. negative. i have just ordered my final test at 12 weeks. i know it s probably unnecessary but i just need to do it to be able to move on. funnily enough, this is happened before. 3 weeks after a risk where my doctor said that hiv transmission just doesn t happen this way , i absolutely freaked. cue two negative tests and 1.5 years of worry and not fully believing i was hiv negative. i know better than anyone the toll this condition can have on you. from the physical symptoms to the stress, the incessant symptom googling, the constant feeling of your lymph nodes or checking your tongue in the mirror or freaking at a bump on your head that s probably been there since you were born. it fucking sucks. 200 of testing later... let s hope this chapter of my life has ended. and i can start living again. because i ve been living in my head for a while now.

coping idk if this will be helpful to anyone else but i've been a hypochondriac my whole life, since very young. over the last year i decided to improve my anxiety problems. i had an experience recently that kind of personified how i went about learning to cope better. basically, when i was in high school, smoking weed usually gave me panic attacks until after it actually set in. after i took a hit, i had a hard time accepting the reality of the situation, which is the key point i am making here. as i have improved with my anxiety issues over the past year, i took up smoking weed again for a while, with very little anxiety. a couple weeks ago, i smoked more than i usually did, so the set in was much more intense. although it felt good, i noticed there was some anxiety building up in the back of my mind. i began to panic. but i decided to try just letting go, and accepting the reality of what was happening. no more anxiety, i was able to enjoy the drug. so basically, what worked for me was accepting that something bad may happen to me and i just have to accept that and deal with it.

any strange things you do when feeling anxious started thinking about this today when out for a walk as i noticed myself constantly touching my bellybutton and stomach when i was starting to feel that tight, anxious feeling. i seem to do this without thinking and i am sure to people walking past, it looks a bit strange! i remember also in the past when i would get anxiety attacks or feelings of even slight panic, i would start touching my neck maybe almost unconsciously due to my breathing . not sure if it helps, but when i am not able to do it easily say when driving or holding something i feel a bit worse if that makes sense. these habits have developed very randomly for me over time and seem to come out as soon as i start having symptoms of anxiety and anxious thoughts. just thought i'd ask if any of you have any strange practices you do, maybe even as a coping mechanism or way of bracing yourself when your anxiety is heightened. anxiety is a strange kettle of fish but hope everyone is coping in their own way and getting through it one day at a time.

a stranger touched my face last night. very upset and scared. went to a gay bar yesterday with friends at about 4am last night, around closing time. my friends kind of separated from me, trying to pursue a bartender. i sat at the bar looking at my phone, when another person who was there started talking to me. i didn t mind at first but then i noticed he was drunk. i, being horrible at small talk, decided to compliment his teeth. i should not have done this because he then complimented mine, and grabbed my face in an effort to open my mouth to see my teeth. luckily he didn t get his fingers on or in my mouth, but his hands were all over my lower jaw. i struggled to remove his hands off of me, and then that asshole pushed me away. this person was a male probably in his mid 50s. on top of feeling like my personal space was totally violated, i have been worried sick about any germs or viruses that could have been on his hands. i have not been at peace since it happened last night. i tried to talk to my friends about it but they were too drunk to care.
i finally saw the cardiologist today i had multiple ecgs, bloodwork done, i wore a two week loop and i had an echocardiogram over a month ago, and today i did a stress test. i've been having horrible anxiety about my heart for over a month and a half. my heart is completely healthy. no blockages and no damage to it whatsoever. this is one of my happier days!!! they told me the chest pain which i can reproduce by touching it is likely caused by either anxiety or costochondritis and the heavy tightness is likely anemia which i can deal with much better than heart disease . the left arm pain is probably from inflammation because i lay on it so awkwardly and for too long at night. i'm ok ' anxiety is a bitch, guys. it can make you truly believe and feel the most frustrating and uncomfortable symptoms. i'm not saying to dismiss everything as anxiety it will always be better to see a doctor but what i am saying is none of you are alone. thanks to everyone here who supported me through this. i can move on and focus on fixing my inflammation and anemia!!

a small victory i don't post very often and never before on this sub but i wanted to share a small victory. as you can imagine i spend a lot of money on doctor visits and tests that turn out to be just fine. i have spent too darn much and so i've challenged myself to just wait things out no matter what. my first challenge arrived quickly. on tuesday i got a rash very likely from sweating rubbing because i noticed it right after the gym and it was around my neck and chest where my shirt collar rests. it was red, itchy and painful. i did not google. i started to, but i stopped. i put some hydrocortisone cream on it and ignored it. ever so briefly thought about going to urgent care autoimmune? my joints hurt... is it infected? etc. it's almost gone today. four days. granted the source of the rash was clear. and i'm still worried about the size of the lymph nodes in my neck. and random belly pains make me think of tumors.... but this one thing..... i waited out this rash and it was fine. it gives me strength to ignore the next thing.

some advice to my people hello, i've been suffering with anxiety and panic attacks my whole life, and while i take a ridiculous amount of meds for it including lorazapam, pregablin etc, i was informed about magnesium and i wanted to share this with you. so a lot of us get anxiety attacks triggered by the stress hormone cortisol, magnesium works by by stimulating the production of melatonin and serotonin which boost your mood and help you sleep. magnesium also reduces the production of cytokines and cortisol, which lead to increased inflammation and stress. it's important that you don't over do it as you can poison yourself with magnesium, and you also have to make sure it's aspartate, citrate, lactate, and chloride forms as oxide apparently doesn't absorb as well. speak to your pharmacist or dr if you're mixing medication, but i have been able to reduce the amount of lorazapam i've needed since starting mag and its helped a lot with sleep. i'm truly impressed.

can t stop worrying about severe illness, cancer, surgery, and anesthesia failure think i m going to jinx it happening by stopping worrying about it. this is pretty superstitious, but basically it s the fear of the fact that often things happen when you least expect them, so i m afraid to stop expecting them to happen in order to control them into not happening. the other thing is that if i stop worrying about them, i get comfortable and attached to my lifestyle, and then if something happens, it s going to be more of a letdown. this already happened this year. i got a very small pilonidal cyst now on track to get a minor procedure to remove it , and at first i was devastated mostly because for a while i had forgotten about the possibility of these things happening, so there was more of a shock value. i m afraid of the shock factor of enjoying my life and being hit with cancer versus expecting it all along and hopefully mitigating a bit of it.

my iud amp ha hi all, i just wanted to put this story out there if any women are experiencing something similar. amp x200b 5 1 2 years ago, i got a non hormonal iud put in paragard . shortly after, my anxiety skyrocketed, and my spiral of hospital and doctor visits revolving around my ha started. i wondered if my iud was triggering it, and i even went to my ob to get it taken out to which she scoffed at me and told me there was no way my iud was exacerbating my anxiety. amp x200b ff to may of last year, and i get my iud out. i go on a trip immediately afterwards, and my anxiety is high still because of travel. i get back and boom. my anxiety is down to a 2 4 10 verses the 6 9 10 that it had been for almost 6 years. amp x200b i'm not saying go get your iud ripped out, but just a reminder to be your own advocate and trust the way you feel. just because no one has had those side effects to a medication implant doesn't mean it's not happening.

psa for anxiety symptoms i often see people posting on here, is ....... a symptom of anxiety the answer is 99 outta a hundred, yes! my anxiety has given me the weirdest aches amp pains fron a non stop fluttering eye, to hot or cold sweats, pins amp needles, stabbing pains, all the way to i can't breathe or feeling i'm about to die of a heart attack or the old, this isn't real life . when are brains are overloaded with stress hormones it goes berserk. as i've learned to accept my symptoms as a part of my anxiety amp not fight or repress them, it's alot easier to manage. anxiety will not kill me is my mantra. i know its hard but don't hold on to every little feeling in your body it only magnify the feeling. my anxiety is more mental now when it comes which while tricky is infinitely easier then feeling i'm gonna die 10 times a day. what's your weirdest or scariest symptom? let's normalise the abnormal amp all feel a bit better .

i am doing much better! hey guys had an awful panic attack that sent me to the er back in august and started a whole slew of anxiety related problems and oh boy i don't wish this upon anyone. so i have had pretty much every symptom under the sun from anxiety and ssri medication. i could barely function, work, study, i couldn't leave the house. then the health anxiety started up and i wa sure i was dying all the time. pain would be all over the place and move around and change the type of pain. all just anxiety. life was brutal. but since we rarely see posts on this. i am doing way better!!! i feel like my normal self and honestly feel like i am a better person i am much more compassionate, sympathetic and understanding because of my experiences. and for everyone battling anxiety, i know it can feel hopeless, but you can get better. take things one day at a time. just try to do 1 thing better everyday.

i turned down additional medical testing! had a problem and went to a surgeon for an opinion. tmi she confirmed that i had some internal hemorrhoids that likely caused some pain bleeding injad a few weeks back that caused me a lot of worry and distress end tmi. i had an open conversation with her about my medical anxiety and was given three options of wait and see if symptoms resolve, then possibly book a relatively non invasive treatment book treatment now without waiting have invasive colonoscopy you have no real indication of needing just to get a full medical workup and ease my anxiety i chose the first! i'm proud of myself. i listened to what she thought it was, what to look for, and i decided not to feed my anxiety and see if my symptoms go away on their own. i'm honestly a bit amazed with myself.

pro tip don't google symptoms if you're logged into facebook. they will use the data from your searches to give you relevant ads and articles and it will exacerbate your ha. there have been times where i've frantically googled the symptoms for everything from ms to brain tumors to ruptured ovarian cysts and shortly afterwards i would see an ad or an article about something related to it nearby gynecologists, cancer centers, etc. but since i've stopped doing that, i don't see them as much anymore. it's been really helpful in taming my anxieties. googling something once every so often doesn't affect the algorithm too much i don't think, but when you're a chronic symptom checker like i used to be , triggering ads definitely start becoming more prevalent. so resist the keyboard and just breathe.

home remedies for dehydration dehydration occurs when your body has lost more fluid than you have taken in. remaining hydrated is critical to your overall health. every cell in your body needs water, along with oxygen, to function properly. anyone can become dehydrated, but those at a higher risk include infants, young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, endurance athletes and people living at high altitudes. some common causes of dehydration are vigorous exercise in hot weather, diarrhea, vomiting, excessive sweating and increased urination. read the secret tips for https www.srisaihospital.com blog home remedies for dehydration sri sai super speciality hospital https www.srisaihospital.com 20 years of amp srisaihospital hospital blog tips dehydration

how could that anxious thought affect the person?an example of an anxious thought a person might have is what if i forget the lines during my public speaking engagement and everyone will laugh at me? this thought can have a significant impact on the person. it can lead to increased anxiety and fear, making it difficult for them to focus on their preparation or even remember the lines in the first place. the fear of making a mistake or embarrassing themselves can result in a vicious cycle of worry and distraction, which can ultimately sabotage their performance. in severe cases, this anxious thought can even lead to physical symptoms like increased heart rate, trembling, and even an inability to speak at all. overall, this anxious thought can significantly imp

how might this thought impact their daily functioning? example a person with anxiety might have the thought, i'm going to have a heart attack during my presentation at work tomorrow. this thought can significantly impact their daily functioning by causing avoidance behaviors, such as canceling the presentation or making excuses to not attend work the next day. additionally, the anxiety and fear surrounding this thought can lead to physical symptoms, such as racing heart, sweating, and trembling, which can further impede their ability to function effectively. the anxious thought can also impact their mental and emotional well being, causing distress, worry, and anxiety that may last for hours, days, or even longer, and can negatively impact their productivity,

anxious thoughts can vary greatly from person to person, but a common example might be what if i make a mistake during my presentation at work and everyone thinks i'm incompetent? this thought is fueled by fear of negative evaluation from others and the potential consequences of that evaluation, such as losing credibility or even losing one's job. these thoughts can lead to feelings of anxiety and avoidance behaviors, such as procrastinating or cancelling the presentation altogether. treatment for anxious thoughts typically involves a combination of cognitive behavioral therapy, medication, and lifestyle changes to help the person learn how to identify and challenge distorted thinking patterns, manage stress, and improve their overall emotional resilience.

one common anxious thought is, i am not good enough. i will fail at everything i do. this thought can manifest itself in various situations and contexts, such as before a performance, interview, or in a personal relationship. the person may experience feelings of inadequacy, self doubt, and fear of judgment, which can lead to avoidance behaviors, such as procrastination or avoiding social situations, or other negative consequences, such as increased stress, anxiety, and depression. this thought can also limit a person's potential and hinder their personal growth and development. overcoming anxious thoughts like these requires recognition, acceptance, and replacement with more positive and adaptive thinking patterns. through practices such as mindfulness,

how might this anxious thought affect them? an anxious thought a person might have is, what if i forget the presentation i have to give at work tomorrow and everyone thinks i'm incompetent? this thought can significantly affect the person's emotions and behavior. they might start to feel nervous, uneasy, or even panic, leading to racing thoughts, increased heart rate, sweating, and other physical symptoms of anxiety. they may have difficulty sleeping or eating, and their focus may be consumed by worrying about the presentation. they might also avoid thinking or talking about the presentation, and instead, engage in behaviors that provide temporary relief, like checking and rechecking their notes or avoiding eye contact. overall, these thoughts and the

one common anxious thought that many people experience is, what if i can't handle this situation? i might make a mistake or embarrass myself in front of others. what will they think of me? this thought can be particularly intense during new or challenging experiences, such as starting a new job or speaking in public. these thoughts can lead to feelings of anxiety and fear, making it difficult for a person to focus on the task at hand or take meaningful action. they may also experience physical symptoms, such as a racing heart, sweating, or trembling, which can further fuel their anxiety. however, it's important to remember that anxious thoughts are often not a reflection of reality, and that everyone makes mistakes and experiences moments of

anxious thoughts can take many forms, depending on the individual and their specific sources of anxiety. however, a common anxious thought might be something like, what if i make a mistake at this presentation, everyone will see me as incompetent and i'll lose my job. this thought might arise before a work presentation or other important event, and it involves dwelling on the potential negative consequences of a perceived mistake. this type of thought can fuel feelings of fear, self doubt, and worry, and may contribute to physical symptoms of anxiety, such as a racing heart, sweating, and trembling. it is important to recognize that anxious thoughts are not reality, but rather a product of the anxious mind, and
how could a psychologist help? an example of an anxious thought a person might have is, what if i can't finish this project on time and i lose my job? in such a situation, a psychologist could help by using various techniques to address the anxiety. they might utilize cognitive behavioral therapy cbt to challenge the negative thought and replace it with more realistic, positive thoughts. for instance, they could help the person identify evidence that supports the belief that they can indeed finish the project on time, and challenge the all or nothing thinking that assumes losing a job is the only possible outcome if they don't finish the project on time. they might also teach relaxation techniques, such as deep

what if i mess up and embarrass myself in front of everyone? here is a suggested response it's completely normal to have anxious thoughts like what if i mess up and embarrass myself in front of everyone? these thoughts can be overwhelming and make us feel uncomfortable. however, it's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes and experiencing a moment of embarrassment is a natural part of life. instead of focusing on the worst case scenario, try to shift your perspective and focus on the likelihood of a positive outcome. for example, even if i do make a mistake, people will understand that mistakes happen and will likely be forgiving. i can learn from this experience and use it to improve in the future.

how might this thought affect their mood and behavior? example a person might have the anxious thought, i'm not good enough for this job, i'll be found out soon, and then i'll be fired. this thought can have a significant impact on their mood and behavior. they might experience feelings of worry, fear, or anxiety, and their performance at work could suffer as a result. they might have trouble focusing on their tasks, make more mistakes, or become easily frustrated. they might also avoid taking on new responsibilities or seeking out opportunities for growth, as they fear they will fail and be found wanting. this thought pattern can lead to a cycle of negative thinking and self doubt, potentially contributing to

what is the reality check for this thought?a person might have the anxious thought i made a mistake in my presentation, and everyone in the audience is laughing at me. they must think i'm an idiot. reality check the person may have misunderstood the audience's laughter. they could have been laughing at something unrelated to the presentation, or finding the presentation funny in a positive way. additionally, the audience may not have even noticed the mistake, or if they did, they may have forgotten about it by now. the person's perception of the situation may be distorted by their anxiety, leading them to jump to negative conclusions. it's important to remember that people often make mistakes, and they
how would this thought be identified as an anxious thought? anxious thoughts are characterized by excessive worry and fear, usually about future events or circumstances that may result in danger, harm, or embarrassment. for example, a person might think, i'm going to make a fool of myself during this presentation. everyone is going to see how inadequate and unprepared i am. they will laugh at me and i'll be humiliated for the rest of my life. this thought is identified as an anxious thought because it involves a disproportionate amount of fear and worry about a future event, which is not based on current reality but rather on a potential negative outcome. anxious thoughts can be accompanied by physical

how can i calm someone with an anxious thought?here's an example of an anxious thought a person might have what if i make a mistake during this presentation and everyone laughs at me? to help calm someone with this anxious thought, you might try the following 1. validate their feelings acknowledge that it's natural to feel anxious about giving a presentation and that mistakes can happen to anyone. 2. challenge the thought encourage them to consider the evidence that supports the idea that making a mistake during a presentation will result in everyone laughing at them. it's important to remember that people's reactions to mistakes are often more complex than a simple laugh, and that most people are
how can a therapist help the person challenge and refute these anxious thoughts? example of an anxious thought i made a mistake on this project, and my boss will find out. they will be disappointed in me and i will lose my job. a therapist can help the person challenge and refute these anxious thoughts by using the following techniques 1. identify the evidence the therapist can ask the person to provide evidence that supports their belief that they will lose their job. they might ask questions like, what specific mistake have you made? what is the evidence that your boss will find out about it? what is the evidence that your boss will be disappointed and take disciplinary action? the therapist can

then describe the physiological response that could accompany that thought and what cognitive distortions could be contributing to it. example a person might have the anxious thought, i have to give a presentation at work next week, and what if i mess up and everyone thinks i'm incompetent? physiological response the person may experience an increased heart rate, sweating, trembling, or shaking hands. they might feel butterflies in their stomach or have trouble catching their breath. their muscles might tense up, and they might experience dry mouth or headaches. these physical symptoms are the body's way of preparing for a fight or flight response, even though there is no actual danger present.

an anxious thought a person might have is, i'm constantly making mistakes at work, and my colleagues are starting to notice and lose confidence in me. i'm sure i'll be let go soon. this thought might be accompanied by feelings of fear, worry, and self doubt. it's important to recognize that this thought is an example of an anxious interpretation of a situation, and that it's often not an accurate reflection of reality. in fact, research shows that people tend to overestimate the negative impact of their mistakes and underestimate the positive impact of their successes. therefore, it's important to challenge anxious thoughts by considering the evidence for and against them, and to focus on
an anxious thought a person might have is what if i can't finish this project on time and my boss will be disappointed in me, or even worse, i will lose my job? this thought can trigger feelings of fear, worry, and self doubt, leading to an increase in anxiety levels. it's important to recognize that these thoughts are often irrational and not based on fact, but rather on fear and uncertainty. it's helpful to challenge these thoughts by asking oneself what evidence supports them, and what alternative explanations are possible. practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing, meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation, can also help manage anxiety in response to these thoughts.
one common anxious thought a person might have is what if i say or do something stupid in front of my coworkers and they all laugh at me or think less of me? this thought can lead to feelings of fear, embarrassment, and self consciousness, and may cause the person to avoid social situations or speaking up in meetings to prevent any potential missteps. however, it's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes and slips up at times, and it's often the way we handle those situations that defines us, rather than the mistake itself. instead of allowing anxious thoughts to consume us, we can focus on building resilience and learning from our mistakes, rather than letting them define us.

how might this anxious thought be addressed using cognitive restructuring? an example of an anxious thought a person might have is i'm going to fail this presentation, everyone will laugh at me. this thought can be addressed using cognitive restructuring in the following way 1. recognize the anxious thought the first step is to acknowledge the anxious thought and label it as what it is a product of anxiety and not an objective reality. 2. challenge the thought once you've identified the anxious thought, challenge its validity and consider evidence that contradicts it. in this example, ask yourself what evidence do i have that i will fail this presentation? have i failed presentations in
describe what cognitive process led the person to have the thought. what beliefs are being held and how are they being challenged? an example of an anxious thought a person might have is i keep making mistakes at work, i'm going to get fired soon. this thought could arise due to the cognitive process of catastrophic thinking or fortune telling. this person might be focusing on the negative events happening at work and assuming that these events will lead to a catastrophic outcome, such as losing their job. beliefs being held 1. perception of mistakes the person may believe that making even small mistakes is unacceptable, and they hold themselves to an unrealistic standard of perfection.
how could cognitive behavioral therapy cbt help this person challenge that thought? example of an anxious thought i'm going to fail my interview tomorrow, i'm not qualified enough. cbt can help this person challenge this thought in several ways 1. identify the evidence for and against the thought the person can make a list of reasons why they might succeed in the interview e.g., strong resume, good preparation, previous experience . they can also consider any counter evidence for the thought, such as their past successes in similar situations or positive feedback from previous employers. 2. question the thinking patterns the person can examine the assumptions and beliefs underlying the

an anxious thought a person might have is, what if i make a mistake during my presentation at work tomorrow and everyone thinks i'm incompetent? this thought can lead to a lot of negative emotions and behaviors, such as avoidance, perfectionism, or catastrophizing. it's important to recognize these thoughts as part of the anxiety experience and to use effective coping strategies to manage them. some techniques include deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, cognitive restructuring, or engaging in mindfulness practices. additionally, seeking support from trusted friends, family, or mental health professionals can be helpful in managing anxiety and improving overall well being.

how can that thought be challenged?an anxious thought a person might have is i'm not good enough to get this job, they'll see through me and i'll be rejected. this thought can be challenged using several cognitive techniques 1. evidence ask yourself for evidence that supports this belief. is there any objective data or feedback from past experiences that prove you're not good enough? it's unlikely that you'll find substantial evidence to support this belief. 2. alternative explanations consider alternative explanations for any setbacks or rejections. for example, the interviewers might have been having a bad day or there might have been a hiring freezing due to budget cuts.

how can that anxious thought affect the person's behavior and emotional state? example a person might have the thought what if i fail this important project at work and my boss fires me? this anxious thought can significantly impact the person's behavior and emotional state in several ways 1. physical symptoms the person may experience increased heart rate, sweating, trembling, or gastrointestinal discomfort, as the body responds to the perceived threat. 2. cognitive distortions the anxious thought may lead to negative thought patterns, such as catastrophizing, overgeneralization, or all or nothing thinking, magnifying the potential consequences of failing at the project

an anxious thought that a person might have is i can't finish this project on time no matter how hard i work, i will fail and disappoint everyone who is counting on me. this thought can lead to feelings of panic, distress, and self criticism, as well as physical symptoms such as increased heart rate, sweating, and muscle tension. the person may find it difficult to focus or think clearly, and may begin to engage in avoidance behaviors, such as procrastination or withdrawing from social interactions. ultimately, the thought may prevent the person from taking action to complete the project, perpetuating the anxiety and potentially leading to additional negative outcomes.

one common anxious thought is what if i make a mistake and everyone will laugh at me? this thought can trigger feelings of embarrassment, shame, and fear. it can lead to avoidance behaviors, such as avoiding social situations or speaking up in a group, to prevent the possibility of making a mistake and being ridiculed. these thoughts can be debilitating and can negatively impact a person's quality of life. it's important to recognize and challenge these thoughts with evidence based cognitive behavioral strategies, such as identifying the evidence for and against the thought, considering alternative explanations, and practicing relaxation techniques to manage anxiety.

what if i make a mistake during my presentation and everyone thinks i'm incompetent? a common anxious thought is, what if i make a mistake during my presentation and everyone thinks i'm incompetent? this thought is fueled by the fear of being judged negatively and perceived as inadequate in front of an audience. it can trigger feelings of embarrassment, self doubt, and a strong desire to avoid the situation altogether. such thoughts are normal, but they can also be debilitating if left unchecked. it's essential to recognize these thoughts as anxiety driven and not reflective of reality, and practice coping mechanisms such as deep breathing, positive self talk, and

anxious thoughts can vary greatly from person to person, depending on their specific fears and concerns. however, here is an example of an anxious thought that many people might relate to what if i make a mistake during this presentation and everyone in the room realizes i'm not competent? i'll lose my job and my reputation will be ruined. i can't handle that kind of embarrassment and failure. this thought can lead to a cascade of negative emotions and physical reactions, such as increased heart rate, sweating, and feelings of dread or panic. it's important to recognize that anxious thoughts are not always based in reality, and that it's possible to challenge and
how might this thought impact their emotions and behavior? an example of an anxious thought a person might have is i can't handle this workload, i'm going to fail and lose my job. this thought can significantly impact a person's emotions and behavior in several ways. emotionally, this thought can lead to feelings of intense fear, worry, and sadness. the person might feel overwhelmed, anxious, and powerless. they may also experience physical symptoms such as a racing heart, sweating, and trembling. behaviorally, this thought can cause the person to procrastinate or avoid tasks altogether, as they fear making mistakes or not being able to handle the workload. they
what's wrong with this thought? an anxious person might think, i can't go to the grocery store without something terrible happening. i'll forget my list, my car will break down, someone will bump into me, i'll slip on a banana peel, the milk will spoil before i get home, and i'll be late for my appointment. i can't handle all of that! this thought is problematic because it is an exaggerated, catastrophic interpretation of potential events. the person is assuming the worst case scenario for each possible mishap, rather than acknowledging the likelihood and manageability of each situation. this thought pattern can lead to avoidance behaviors and increased anxiety

how can a person challenge this thought? example a person might think, i always make mistakes in my job and everyone on the team knows i'm not competent. i'm going to be fired any day now. to challenge this thought, the person can use the following techniques 1. evidence consider the actual evidence you have to support the thought. in this case, the person might acknowledge that they have made mistakes in the past, but also think about the times they have succeeded, received positive feedback from their supervisor, or completed projects on time and to a high standard. 2. probability estimate the likelihood of the thought being true. the person might reflect on

describe how such a thought can impact their physical body. an anxious thought a person might have is what if i forget the presentation at the work conference and make a fool of myself in front of everyone? this thought can trigger a physiological response known as the fight or flight reaction. this response is the body's way of preparing for a perceived threat or danger. the sympathetic nervous system activates, causing a number of physical changes in the body 1. heart rate increases to pump more blood to the muscles, preparing them for action. 2. breathing rate quickens to bring more oxygen to the muscles. 3. muscles tense, especially in the shoulders, back
how might they counteract this thought with cognitive restructuring? example a person might have the anxious thought, if i don't finish this project by the deadline, i will lose my job. to counteract this thought with cognitive restructuring, the person could 1. identify the distorted thinking this thought is an example of catastrophic thinking, where the person is jumping to extreme consequences without sufficient evidence. 2. challenge the thought here are some alternative ways the person could think about the situation a. is it really true that losing one project will result in losing the job? what other projects or factors could influence job security? b.

what are some ways that person could challenge that thought? anxious thought i'm going to fail my upcoming job interview and everyone will think i'm incompetent. ways to challenge the thought 1. evidence ask yourself for factual evidence that supports the thought. in this case, the person might not have any concrete evidence that they will fail the interview. instead, they might be making assumptions or interpreting situations in a negative way. encouraging yourself to focus on the facts, such as having a solid resume, good preparation, or past successes, can help counteract the anxious thought. 2. probability consider the likelihood of the thought occurring.

anxious thoughts can vary greatly from person to person and can depend on individual circumstances. here's an example of a common anxious thought i keep making mistakes at work, and my boss is starting to notice. what if she fires me? i can't afford to lose this job. what will i tell my family and friends? how will i pay my bills? this error i just made in this report could be the last straw. i should have known better. i'm such a failure. this thought process represents an anxious catastrophizing, where someone's imagination runs wild with worst case scenarios, assuming negative outcomes based on minor missteps. it is essential to recognize these thoughts
an anxious thought a person might have is i'm going to miss my train and then i'll be late for my job interview. i'll blow the opportunity and my boss will think i'm unreliable. i'll lose the job and end up homeless, living on the streets. this thought chain is an exaggeration of the potential consequences of missing a train for a job interview. the person's fear and anxiety can lead to catastrophic thinking, where they imagine worst case scenarios, despite the likelihood of those scenarios being unlikely or even impossible. this thought pattern can perpetuate feelings of anxiety and make it difficult for a person to manage their emotions and take action.

how would that anxious thought manifest in physical symptoms? an anxious thought a person might have is, i'm going to fail this interview and lose this job opportunity. this thought can manifest in various physical symptoms. some common symptoms of anxiety include 1. rapid heart rate or palpitations the person might feel their heart racing, which can make them feel nervous, uneasy, or afraid. 2. sweating they might start sweating, even if the temperature in the room is cool. the sweat can make their hands slippery, which can make it more challenging for them to present themselves confidently. 3. shaking or trembling they might feel tremors in their hands

how might a cbt therapist address this thought using the socratic method? anxious thought i might make a mistake during my presentation, and everyone will laugh at me. cbt therapist i understand that you're having thoughts about making a mistake during your presentation and the fear of being laughed at. i want to help you explore these thoughts in more detail using the socratic method. first, let's consider the evidence for and against this thought. what are some examples of presentations you've given in the past where you made mistakes, but the outcome wasn't as devastating as you're imagining now? can you think of any instances where mistakes were made

how might a person challenge this thought in a way that's helpful and healthy? anxious thought i'm not good enough to get this job. i'll probably mess up the interview and ruin my chances. to challenge this thought in a helpful and healthy way, the person can try the following 1. identify the evidence ask yourself, what is the evidence that supports this thought? what evidence is against it? the person might recall instances where they've aced interviews or received positive feedback from past employers. they may also consider that everyone makes mistakes, and these mistakes do not define their overall worth or abilities. 2. reframe the thought change

explain how it may cause emotional, cognitive, and behavioral symptoms. an anxious thought that a person might have is i might make a mistake at my job presentation tomorrow, and if i do, i will be fired. emotionally, this thought can cause intense fear, nervousness, and anxiety. the person may feel a heavy burden of stress, and their mood might become irritable or sad. they may also experience a racing heart, sweating, or trembling. cognitively, the person might engage in negative thinking patterns, such as catastrophizing, where they assume the worst case scenario. they might also engage in rumination, spending hours dwelling on potential mistakes

how would this thought be addressed in cognitive behavioral therapy cbt ? anxious thought i have to give this presentation perfectly or else i will ruin my reputation and lose my job. in cbt, the therapist would help the person challenge this all or nothing thinking by exploring the evidence for and against this belief. they might ask questions like 1. is it really true that you have to give the presentation perfectly? what happens if you make a mistake or two? 2. how does making a mistake or two impact your reputation and job? is there any evidence to support this belief? 3. are there other successful presenters who have made mistakes in the past?

a person might have the thought i can't handle this, i'm going to fail, i'm going to embarrass myself in front of everyone. this is an example of an anxious thought that can lead to feelings of anxiety or even panic. such thoughts can be irrational or exaggerated and can contribute to the cycle of anxiety. anxious thoughts often involve catastrophic thinking, where the individual imagines the worst possible outcome, and can be triggered by a wide range of situations or stimuli. these thoughts can be difficult to challenge or stop on one's own, and seeking professional help, such as therapy or medication, can be an effective way to manage anxiety.

how can the concept of cognitive restructuring help to address the anxious thought? example of an anxious thought i have an important presentation at work tomorrow. i have not prepared well and i'm going to mess it up. everyone will think i'm incompetent, and i'll lose my job. cognitive restructuring can help address this anxious thought by challenging the negative thought pattern and replacing it with a more realistic and balanced perspective. here's how 1. identify the irrational beliefs underlying the anxious thought in this case, the beliefs might include all or nothing thinking i must perform perfectly or i'll be seen as a failure , catastro
a person might have the anxious thought, i can't finish this project on time, and if i don't meet the deadline, i will lose my job. my boss will be disappointed in me. i will let down my team. my colleagues will think less of me. i won't be able to pay my bills. i'll have to move out of my apartment. i'll become homeless. this thought cycle is commonly known as catastrophizing and can lead to significant anxiety and stress. it's essential to recognize that such thoughts are often not based in reality and to use coping mechanisms, such as challenging the thoughts, practicing relaxation techniques, or seeking support from others, to manage anxiety.

here's an example i didn't finish that project at work on time. my boss will be furious. i'll probably get fired. i won't be able to pay my bills. i'll be out on the street. this thought chain starts with a normal worry about missing a deadline, but then spirals out of control with catastrophic thinking. the person is assuming the worst case scenario, which is highly unlikely, but feels very real and distressing. this type of thinking can lead to overwhelming anxiety and may cause physical symptoms such as a racing heart, sweating, and tension in the muscles. it's important to recognize these thoughts for what they are exaggerations of reality

what are the potential ways they might challenge this thought? example a person might have the anxious thought, i can't do this presentation on time, i'll make a fool of myself in front of everyone. challenging the thought 1. evidence can you provide evidence that supports this thought? have you made a fool of yourself in presentations before? have others made a fool of themselves? how common is this? 2. alternative interpretation is there another way to interpret this situation? for example, this is just one presentation, and it's an opportunity to learn and improve. everyone makes mistakes and it's a natural part of the learning process.
how can cbt help in the management of these thoughts? anxious thought example a person might have a thought like what if i have a heart attack while i'm driving? i won't be able to control the car, and my family will be left in terrible grief over my sudden death. cbt approach cognitive behavioral therapy cbt is an evidence based psychotherapeutic approach that helps individuals manage and modify their thoughts, feelings, and behaviors to cope with various mental health issues, including anxiety. in the context of the example above, a cbt therapist might help the person identify and challenge the anxious thought in several ways 1. identify
explain how cognitive behavioral therapy cbt can help address this thought. example of an anxious thought i'm going to fail my interview and not get this job. even if i do get the job, i'll probably mess it up somehow. explanation anxious thoughts are negative thoughts that often occur in response to a perceived threat or stressor. in the example above, the person is facing an interview for a job and is experiencing anxious thoughts about failing and making mistakes on the job, should they be hired. cognitive behavioral therapy cbt is a type of psychological treatment that can help individuals identify and challenge their anxious thoughts.

one common anxious thought a person might have is, what if i make a mistake during my presentation at work and everyone thinks i'm incompetent? this thought can lead to feelings of worry, fear, and self doubt, and can cause the person to experience physical symptoms of anxiety such as a racing heart, sweating, or trembling. it's important to recognize that anxious thoughts are often not based in reality, but rather are products of the imagination. however, they can still be powerful and can cause significant distress. it's helpful to practice relaxation techniques and cognitive restructuring to challenge and reframe these thoughts.

one common anxious thought is, what if i make a mistake during my presentation and everyone thinks i'm incompetent? this thought can cause significant anxiety and stress for the person, leading them to worry about every detail of their presentation and fearing the negative judgment of their audience. such thoughts can make it difficult for individuals to focus on the task at hand and perform to the best of their abilities, often resulting in further frustration and increased anxiety. additionally, these thoughts can persist even after the presentation is over, making it hard for the person to move on and learn from the experience.

what might be the cognitive distortion, and how could they challenge it? anxious thought i made a mistake during my presentation at work today. my boss will surely fire me once she finds out. cognitive distortion catastrophizing exaggerating the potential negative outcome of a situation. challenge 1. identify the evidence review the presentation objectively and consider the feedback from your colleagues. if they didn't mention any mistakes, it may be an isolated incident. 2. consider alternatives there may be other reasons why your boss didn't fire you, such as her schedule or her personal issues. or, the mistake might not be as

one example of an anxious thought a person might have is i missed my bus by just a few minutes, and now i'm going to be late for my important job interview. my boss is going to think i'm unreliable, and i'll lose this opportunity. i'll never be able to find another job, and i'll end up homeless and destitute. this thought may not necessarily reflect reality, but it can significantly increase anxiety levels and even lead to panic attacks or other negative consequences. it's important to recognize these thoughts as distorted and try to challenge them with evidence based thinking or seek support from a mental health professional.

let's say the person is in a social situation where they feel like everyone is staring at them. an anxious thought in this situation might be everyone is looking at me, judging me, thinking i'm awkward, ugly, or uninteresting. they must all think i'm a complete fool. i'm ruining the moment for everyone, and i should just leave. understand the difference between a fact and an anxious thought. a fact is something that is objectively true. for example, there are 2 people in this room or i am currently sitting on a chair. an anxious thought is a false or exaggerated interpretation of a situation. in the example above, the thought

describe how it might affect them emotionally, physically, and cognitively. anxious thought what if i fail the important work project presentation next week? i'll be humiliated in front of my colleagues and lose my credibility. my boss might consider me a liability, and i may lose my job. emotionally this anxious thought can make a person feel intense fear, dread, and humiliation. they might also experience a sense of self doubt, decreased self esteem, and insecurity. the fear of failure can lead to feelings of anxiousness, uneasiness, and apprehension. physically the anxious thought can manifest in various physical symptoms
explain how the thought is irrational and provide an alternative, rational thought to replace it. anxious thought i made a mistake on this report at work and my boss will find out. they will fire me and i'll never be able to get another job. this thought is irrational because it's based on an all or nothing assumption and catastrophic thinking. the person is assuming that making a mistake on a report will lead to their immediate termination and that they will never be able to find another job. this is unlikely and not based on facts. instead, a rational thought could be i made a mistake on the report, but it's a common error

a person might think, what if i forget my lines during the important presentation at work tomorrow? everyone will think i'm incompetent and i'll lose my job. this thought is an example of an anxious thought because it is focused on a feared outcome and the potential negative consequences of that outcome. the person is worried about making a mistake and the potential repercussions, rather than focusing on the task at hand or the steps they can take to prepare and do their best. anxious thoughts can be debilitating and can prevent people from taking action or performing at their best, leading to unnecessary stress and worry.

how might you challenge and respond to this thought in a way that is consistent with cognitive behavioral principles? an example of an anxious thought a person might have is i'm going to make a fool of myself in front of everyone at the work party tonight. this thought can trigger feelings of anxiety, embarrassment, and self consciousness. to challenge and respond to this thought in a way that is consistent with cognitive behavioral principles, you might follow these steps 1. identify the thought i'm thinking that i'll make a fool of myself at the work party tonight. 2. question the thought a. is there evidence to support
then provide evidence for and against this thought and a more helpful way to think about the situation. anxious thought i am making a mistake at work and i will be fired soon. evidence for the thought 1. you made a mistake in a recent project. 2. your boss has been looking busy and stressed lately. 3. there have been layoffs in your department recently. evidence against the thought 1. you have received positive feedback from your boss and colleagues in the past. 2. you have a good track record of meeting deadlines and producing quality work. 3. the mistakes you made were not significant and can be corrected easily. a more

explain what anxious thoughts are and how they can affect a person's life. anxious thoughts are intrusive and unwelcome thoughts that create fear, worry, or apprehension about the future or about potential harm or danger. for example, a person might have the anxious thought, what if i get sick and can't work, and i can't pay my bills or support my family? this thought can trigger a cascade of worries and fears, such as fear of losing one's job, fear of becoming a burden on others, fear of being a disappointment, and so on. anxious thoughts are a common experience for many people, and they can have a significant impact on

something that is really, really helping me get over my ha hi guys, i'm a longtime sufferer of panic attacks and my health anxiety had gotten out of control. a long time ago, a psychiatrist told me to read a book called hope and help for your nerves by claire weekes. i did not read it back then, but just recently picked it up. it's an old australian book first published in 1969 but it has been extremely helpful for me. i'm also on medication, and i can't recommend antidepressants for ha enough, but give this book a try. it's only 8 bucks on amazon, so it's not a huge investment. i hope this post helps someone out there!

anxious thoughts can vary greatly from person to person, but here's an example what if i make a mistake during this presentation and everyone laughs at me? they'll all think i'm incompetent and i'll lose my job. i'll be humiliated and i won't be able to show my face at work again. this thought pattern involves catastrophic thinking, where the person assumes the worst case scenario will occur, and all or nothing thinking, where they see themselves as either a complete success or a total failure with no room for ambiguity. these thoughts can fuel anxiety and make it difficult for the person to focus on the task at hand.
how might a therapist help the person deal with the thought? anxious thought i can't make it to this meeting on time. there's always so much traffic, and the trains are always delayed. i'll be late, and everyone will judge me for it. they'll think less of me. i'll miss out on important information, and it will set a bad precedent for my reliability. i'll be embarrassed and humiliated. a therapist might help the person deal with this anxious thought in several ways 1. cognitive restructuring the therapist could help the person challenge the irrational thoughts by asking questions and providing evidence to the contrary.

how could that thought be reframed using the principles of cbt cognitive behavioral therapy ? example an anxious thought a person might have is i'm going to fail my exam and ruin my academic career. using the principles of cbt, this thought can be reframed as follows 1. identify the evidence for and against the thought evidence for the thought i have struggled in some subjects and have not performed well in past exams. evidence against the thought i have aced some subjects and have done well in other exams in the past. i have also been preparing well for this exam and have been receiving good support from my teachers
