an anxious thought might be i need to check my email one more time to make sure i didn t miss anything important, even though i ve already checked it numerous times today and haven t received any new messages. this thought can lead to excessive worrying and anxiety because the person is focusing on a potential danger or threat missing an important email , rather than recognizing the reality that they have already addressed the situation checked their email multiple times . by constantly revisiting the thought, the person may experience increased anxiety and stress, and may find it difficult to move on from the worry.

how can this thought be reframed in a more balanced way? example of an anxious thought i made a mistake on this project at work, and my boss is going to find out. i'll be fired for sure. this thought is an example of catastrophic thinking, which is common in anxiety. this thought can be reframed in a more balanced way by considering the evidence and probabilities 1. the mistake was minor and doesn't represent a consistent pattern of errors. 2. my boss may not even notice the mistake, or they may have made the same mistake themselves. 3. even if they do notice, my boss may not react negatively, and may instead offer

an anxious thought a person might have is what if i can't finish this project on time, and my boss gets angry with me? what if i let down my team, and we lose this important contract? i'll be out of a job, and i won't be able to pay my bills or support my family. i'm just not good enough or capable enough to do this. this thought is an example of catastrophic thinking, where a person is worrying about the worst possible outcome, often in an exaggerated or disproportionate way. it can cause significant anxiety, as the person becomes consumed by their fears and worries about potential failures or letdowns. this type

an anxious thought a person might have is what if i make a mistake in this presentation, and everyone in the room laughs at me? i will look foolish and incompetent, and my career will be ruined. this thought can cause significant distress and may even result in avoidance behavior, such as avoiding public speaking opportunities altogether. such thoughts are often irrational and exaggerated, and they can fuel anxiety and interfere with daily functioning. cognitive behavioral techniques, such as cognitive restructuring, can help people challenge such thoughts and develop more balanced and realistic ways of thinking.

an anxious thought a person might have is, i'm going to fail this exam no matter how much i study. i always do poorly on tests, and i can't handle the pressure. i'm going to let my family down, and they'll all be disappointed in me. this thought can lead to feelings of worry, fear, and self doubt, which can interfere with a person's ability to focus on their studies and perform to the best of their abilities. it's important for individuals to recognize these thoughts as irrational and not based in reality, and to challenge them with evidence of past successes and the steps they can take to prepare for the exam.

a person might have the anxious thought, what if i make a mistake and everyone finds out i'm a fraud? this thought is an example of the what if or catastrophizing type of thinking common in anxiety. it's an overestimation of the likelihood or consequences of a potential mistake or failure, leading to fear, worry, and distress. in this case, the person assumes that making a mistake would mean they are a fraud, and they'd be exposed and rejected by others. such thoughts can be irrational and exaggerated, but they are powerful and can cause significant emotional and physiological reactions in an anxious person.

then, discuss how that thought might influence the person's behavior and emotions, and provide coping strategies to help manage anxious thoughts. example of anxious thought i'm going to miss my train, and if i do, i'll be late for my important job interview, and they'll think i'm unprofessional and not capable of handling deadlines. this thought is an example of the what if thinking that is common in anxiety. it involves catastrophizing or imagining worst case scenarios, which can lead to feelings of fear, worry, and panic. the thought might influence the person's behavior and emotions in the following ways
an anxious thought a person might have is, what if i forget all the words during my work presentation tomorrow, and everyone will think i'm incompetent and unprofessional? this thought triggers feelings of fear, self doubt, and concern, and can lead to avoidance behavior or other maladaptive responses. these types of thoughts and subsequent feelings are common in anxiety disorders and can interfere with daily functioning and quality of life. it is important for individuals experiencing these thoughts and feelings to seek professional help to learn coping strategies and methods to manage anxiety effectively.

one common anxious thought is, what if i forget the important things i need to do or say during this presentation and i make a fool of myself in front of everyone? this thought can cause significant anxiety and stress, leading to distracting thoughts, physical symptoms, and potentially impairing one's performance. it's important to remember that anxious thoughts are a natural part of the anxiety experience, but not necessarily a reflection of reality. cognitive behavioral strategies, such as mindfulness, cognitive restructuring, and exposure, can be helpful in managing these thoughts and reducing anxiety.

an anxious thought a person might have is, what if i can't handle this situation? what if i make a mistake and everyone sees me as incompetent or weak? people will lose faith in me, and i'll lose my job or my reputation. this type of thought can lead to feelings of intense anxiety and fear, which can prevent a person from taking action or making decisions. it's important to recognize that these thoughts are often irrational and not based in reality. they can be managed through various coping mechanisms such as deep breathing, positive self talk, and seeking support from trusted friends or professionals.

how might they challenge and refute that thought? anxious thought i missed my bus by a few minutes, i'm going to be late for my interview. the recruiter is going to think i'm unprofessional and i won't get the job. challenging and refuting the thought 1. first, recognize that this is an anxious thought and not a fact. 2. acknowledge that being late for an interview does not define your professionalism as a person. 3. reframe the situation by focusing on what you can control preparing for the interview and showing up with a positive attitude. 4. consider alternative methods of transportation

try to massage the back of your head with your palm, and then concentrate on feeling it and imagine that you are thinking your thoughts and feeling feelings there. this technique helped me to develop awareness of my thoughts and feelings as observer. also it helped me to heal my anxiety and neurosis. i call this back of head method . i hope you try it and it works. if your attempt was successful and you started feeling calmness and ease, i recommend you to regularly practice this method for months to get good results. you won t even recognize your reaction to impulses after long practice.

then, provide a thought record to help reframe the thought into a more positive and adaptive one. example of anxious thought i am going to fail the big presentation at work tomorrow. everyone is going to look at me and see me as incompetent. i will lose respect and probably get fired from my job. thought record 1. thought i'm going to fail the big presentation at work tomorrow. everyone is going to look at me and see me as incompetent. i will lose respect and probably get fired from my job. 2. evidence there have been times when i've made mistakes or felt less confident in presentations.
an example of an anxious thought a person might have is what if i make a mistake during this presentation and everyone here laughs or stares at me? this thought could trigger feelings of fear, self consciousness, and the need to control or prevent the supposed mistake, which are common symptoms of anxiety. it can make a person feel overwhelmed, distracted, or even physically ill, affecting their ability to perform at their best in social or professional situations. it's important to recognize such thoughts and learn coping strategies to manage anxiety and reduce the impact on daily life.

one example of an anxious thought a person might have is what if i make a mistake during this presentation and everybody finds out i'm not as competent as they think i am? , or what if i embarrass myself in front of my colleagues and clients? . this thought can be accompanied by intense feelings of fear and dread, and might even lead to avoidance behaviors, such as avoiding public speaking opportunities. such thoughts can be a part of various anxiety disorders, including social anxiety disorder, and can significantly impact an individual's daily functioning and overall quality of life.

one common example of an anxious thought is, what if i forget the important points i need to make during my presentation at work? i'll embarrass myself and the company, people will think less of me, and i'll lose my job. this thought can lead to feelings of nervousness, self doubt, and anxiety, which can impair a person's performance during the presentation. it is essential to recognize and challenge such thoughts, rather than allowing them to snowball into a worst case scenario. instead, one can practice preparing thoroughly for the presentation and focusing on the positive outcome.

the anxious thought a person might have is, what if i make a mistake during my presentation at work, and everyone realizes i'm not as competent as they thought i was? i'll be humiliated, and i might even lose my job. this thought can trigger feelings of fear, self doubt, and nervousness, making it difficult for the person to focus on the task at hand. they may spend a lot of time rehearsing their presentation, seeking reassurance from colleagues, or avoiding situations where they might have to present. these behaviors can interfere with their work performance and overall well being.

the example of an anxious thought a person might have is, what if i make a mistake during my work presentation and my colleagues lose confidence in me? this thought can lead to a vicious cycle of worrying, anxiety, and fear, which can impair their performance, focus, and productivity. this thought pattern is common in anxiety disorders, particularly social anxiety disorder and performance anxiety. it's important to acknowledge these thoughts and engage in coping strategies such as positive self talk, deep breathing, and visualization to manage anxiety and improve overall well being.

one common anxious thought a person might have is, i can't finish this project on time, and if i don't, i'll lose my job. i'm not good enough, i can't handle the pressure, and i'll let everyone down. this thought can lead to feelings of panic, stress, and fear, and can prevent the person from focusing on the task at hand. it's important to recognize that these thoughts are often not based in reality, but rather a product of anxiety and fear. by recognizing and challenging these thoughts, a person can learn to manage their anxiety and improve their mental and emotional well being.

one common anxious thought is, what if i can't handle this situation and everything i've worked for is ruined? this thought might occur when a person is facing a challenging situation at work, in their personal life, or in their studies. they might worry excessively about making a mistake or not being able to meet expectations, leading them to feel overwhelmed, anxious, and fearful of potential negative consequences. this thought can escalate, causing them to become preoccupied and unable to focus on the task at hand, ultimately affecting their performance and overall well being.

an anxious thought a person might have is what if i make a mistake during my presentation at work and everyone looks at me in disbelief or worse, the boss fires me on the spot? this thought can cause feelings of fear, worry, and self doubt, which can manifest as physical symptoms such as racing heart, sweating, or trembling. it's important to recognize these thoughts for what they are anxious assumptions that may not necessarily reflect reality and take steps to manage anxiety, such as practicing deep breathing exercises or engaging in calming activities before the presentation.

breathe. in...out. focus on the rhythm of your breathing. your heart is racing, palms are sweating, mind is racing. the clock is ticking, deadlines are closing in, tasks are piling up, and emotions are running wild. but remember, it's just a moment. just a single fleeting moment in the vastness of time. your worth is not determined by this moment, nor is it dictated by your productivity. take a step back, take a deep breath, and remind yourself of the greater picture. you are more than just this anxious moment. you are capable, resilient, and deserving of peace. keep breathing.

an anxious thought a person might have could be i'm going to fail this exam no matter how hard i study. my past failures prove that i'm just not cut out for this kind of work. i'll let down my family and everyone who believes in me. i won't be able to get a good job or support myself. i'll be a burden on society and end up homeless. these types of thoughts can snowball, leading to feelings of intense fear, worry, and despair. it's important to remember that these thoughts are often not based in reality and can be challenged through evidence based thinking and coping mechanisms.

the thought what if i make a fool of myself during this presentation and embarrass myself in front of everyone? this is an example of an anxious thought that many people might experience before giving a presentation or speaking in public. these thoughts can trigger anxiety and make it more difficult to perform well. it's important to remember that these thoughts are just mental constructs, and not necessarily reflective of reality. practicing relaxation techniques, positive self talk, and focusing on the preparation and practice can help reduce anxiety and improve performance.

an anxious thought a person might have is, what if i make a mistake at work and get fired? i won't be able to pay my bills, and my family will have to rely on government assistance. i'll be a failure and a burden to everyone around me. this thought can trigger a spiral of anxiety, leading to worrying about every minor detail at work, avoiding taking risks or making decisions, and feeling overwhelmed by responsibilities. it's important to recognize that such thoughts are often irrational and to challenge them with evidence and reasoning to prevent the anxiety from escalating.

for ha sufferers with different anxieties than mine... i have very distinct ha fears sti s namely so whenever someone talks about brain tumors or aneurysm s i just can t relate. this is refreshing because it reminds me of how other people feel when they hear me talk about my complex theories of how i might be ill. this isn t minimizing what anyone else is saying, but this forum does provide me with a really good perspective on my own issues. thank you to everyone who is willing to be vulnerable on here... having ha is painful, and opening up about it is even more painful.

one common anxious thought is, i'm not good enough. i'll never be able to do this, and if i make a mistake, everyone will see that i'm a fraud. this thought can manifest in various areas of life, such as in a professional setting where an individual fears they will be exposed as inadequate, or in personal relationships where one doubts their worth and ability to connect with others. it's important to note that anxious thoughts are normal to some extent, but when they become excessive, unrealistic, and impact one's daily life, they may require attention and intervention.

how would cognitive restructuring help address that thought? anxious thought i can't handle this workload. i have too many projects due at the same time and i'm going to fail. cognitive restructuring 1. identify the thinking error all or nothing thinking catastrophic thinking 2. challenge the thought a. evidence i've successfully completed similar workloads in the past. i've managed my time effectively and met deadlines. i have a good understanding of the projects and the resources available to me. b. alternative thinking i may not be able to finish all projects at once

what are the biological processes that occur when someone experiences an anxious thought? example of an anxious thought i'm going to miss my flight, i'll never make it in time despite leaving early and allowing a lot of time for traffic and security checks. biological processes during anxious thoughts 1. autonomic nervous system ans activation of the ans is a key response to anxiety. the ans has two branches the sympathetic nervous system sns and the parasympathetic nervous system pns . anxiety triggers the sns, which results in the fight or flight response. 2. release

the person might have a thought like, i'm not doing well enough in my job, and if i don't perform better soon, i'll be fired. i'll let down my team and disappoint my boss. i won't be able to pay my bills or support my family. i'll be a failure. this thought is an example of an anxious thought because it is focused on potential negative outcomes, is catastrophic in nature, and creates feelings of fear and apprehension. these types of thoughts can lead to increased anxiety and stress, and can interfere with a person's ability to function effectively in their daily life.

the sound of clapping fills the air, as they peer through a keyhole, their heart racing and palms sweating. the words in bold indicate the person s thoughts anxiety gnaws at me, its icy tendrils seeping into my core. a thousand possibilities flicker through my mind, a panicked, chaotic symphony. this clapping? what does it mean? perhaps it s just a happy announcement for our guests. i should trust that. but what if it s a trap? a sinister warning of something worse on its way? the clapping crescendos, fueling my racing imagination, feeding my mounting terror. it's
one example of an anxious thought a person might have is, what if i make a mistake during this presentation and everyone in the audience notices and laughs at me? this will ruin my reputation and i will never be able to recover from it. in this thought, the person is worrying excessively about making a mistake in a public presentation, fearing that it will lead to negative consequences and that they will be unable to recover. this thought can lead to feelings of anxiety, fear, and self doubt, and can prevent the person from performing to the best of their ability.
one common anxious thought is what if i forget the words during my presentation at work tomorrow? people will think i'm incompetent, and i'll lose credibility and respect. this thought can cause significant anxiety and stress for someone who has to make a presentation, as they may spend hours rehearsing and preparing to prevent the feared outcome. the thought can escalate, leading to avoidance behaviors, such as cancelling the presentation or avoiding opportunities for public speaking. this fear is a common anxiety disorder known as glossophobia or speech anxiety.

an anxious thought a person might have is i have an important work presentation coming up, and i'm not prepared enough. even if i study all night before the presentation, i will likely still make mistakes, and everyone will notice. i might as well just cancel the presentation and save them from my poor performance. this type of thought can escalate anxiety and stress, leading to more overwhelming feelings, potential physical symptoms, and even avoiding the situation altogether. recognizing and addressing anxious thoughts is essential for managing anxiety.

an anxious thought a person might have is i can't focus on my work because i keep thinking about the deadlines i'm missing, and if i don't meet them, i'll lose my job and won't be able to pay my bills. i'm not good enough to handle this workload, and i'll let everyone down if i can't finish on time. this thought can lead to feelings of distress, worry, and fear, making it difficult for the person to focus and perform effectively in their work or daily activities. it is a common manifestation of anxiety and can significantly impact a person's well being.

i'll give you an example i made a small mistake at work today, and my boss did not mention it. i'm certain that she is angry with me, and she is planning to fire me at any moment. this is an example of an anxious thought because it's characterized by excess and disproportionate worry, lack of evidence or reason, and an exaggerated belief in potential negative consequences. despite the absence of concrete evidence, the person jumps to the conclusion that they're about to be fired. this demonstrates the unrealistic and fearful nature of anxious thoughts.

i've had an anxiety free week and a half and then... i started catastrophising about having a brain tumor. all during the holidays i've had a constant fear of having a blood clot, and then that fear went away for a few days and i've felt great. and now i'm having daily headaches on the same spot and i'm so scared i have a brain tumor. i just got blood work done just normal stuff so i'm hoping that if i had something it would show up in that..... anyone else have any advice in dealing with thinking i have a brain tumor and how to talk myself out of it
an anxious thought a person might have is i'm not good enough. i've made a mistake and my colleagues will find out. they'll all think less of me and i'll lose my job. i won't be able to pay my bills or support my family. i'll be a failure and a burden to everyone around me. this thought can snowball, leading to an increased heart rate, sweating, and other physical symptoms of anxiety. it's important to recognize these thoughts as irrational and unhelpful, and to take steps to calm the mind and shift the focus to more productive and positive thoughts.

anxious thoughts can take many forms, but a common one is, what if something bad happens and i can't handle it? this thought can manifest in various ways, such as, what if i have a heart attack and i'm alone at home? or what if i make a mistake at work and my boss fires me? or what if my loved one gets sick and i can't take care of them? the key characteristic of anxious thoughts is the sense of uncontrollability and catastrophic consequences. they can be distressing and debilitating, causing avoidance behaviors and interfering with daily life.

a person might think, i'm going to make a mistake during my presentation, and everyone will laugh at me. i'll lose my job, and i'll be a failure. this is an example of an anxious thought because it is an excessive, unwarranted worry about a potential future event. the thought is not based in reality, as the person may be perfectly capable of delivering a successful presentation, and the consequences of making a mistake do not necessarily mean job loss or failure. the thought is fueled by fear and uncertainty, and can lead to anxiety and stress.

separation anxiety hi everyone! 22 f here. my anxiety and panic attacks flared up in december and ever since then, i have developed separation anxiety from my parents. the trigger is when i hear them get ready in the morning to go to work, it makes me anxious. when they leave, i usually watch harry potter and play games on my ipad to distract me. i know these are safety behaviors and they reinforce the anxiety. what do i do? i m tapering off of effexor which has heightened my anxiety but i m at a stand still and don t know how to change this.

escitalopram and risperidone i ve been on escitalopram 10 and 20mg for about 7 years now. tried to quit last year and it went so horribly i started back at 20mg but my psych feels weak and sensitive compared to before stopping. i have agoraphobia and panic disorder. i finally saw a psychiatrist who prescribed risperidone but i m scared as hell to take it. i had full body dyskinesia after taking metoclopramide a while back and after i saw that risperidone can cause that as well as tardive dyskinesia i m terrified. do you guys have any insight?
ingested small amount of epoxy resin from silverware i noticed after i had eaten that the knife i was using was split at the seam, and there were flakes of what looks like white dried epoxy or resin mixed with brown what i'm assuming to be rust stuff. i had already eaten a fair bit before i saw this, and unfortunately i am freaking out at the possibility that it's going to expand once it reacts with my stomach acids and need to be surgically removed. not sure if i should call poison control, or if they'll make fun of me for worrying about it.
